@Fokko, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @jwi078 and @hgrif to be potential reviewers.

Adding these parameters before `properties` breaks functionality for people using positional arguments. Could you move to the end? Or does that not make sense w.r.t. usage.

Also, adding in every option seems a bit brittle ... As none of these fields are template fields, wouldn't it be better to let users specify a dict and build commands from that? That will work better sqoop API changes.

 I can add in an example later.

Hi @hgrif, good catch. I think most people write it like:
```
sqoop_job = SqoopOperator(
    task_id='sqoop_job',
    conn_id='production_postgres',
    cmd_type='export',
    input_null_string="\\\\N",
    input_null_non_string="\\\\N",
    delimiter="|",
    table="sales",
    export_dir='/apps/hive/warehouse/bi/sales',
    num_mappers='1',
    dag=dag
)
```
Then it doesn't break, but just to be sure.

Regarding supplying a `dict`, I think it is more elegant. On the other side, the operator might be a bit brittle in terms of writing them, but this is done only once. Every time you use an operator, and you have to figure out the command, this might also open up room for errors.
PR against kombu celery/kombu#687 is merged! 💃

This is a CSS modification, no test coverage on CSS.

I will create a Jira issue.
Also, @bolkedebruin codecov says there was a modification to airflow/models.py, but there was none such modification.
Sure ... let me try to do that this weekend.

OK!

Rewriting it is maybe something for another PR. 👍
Why do you think it is not running? According to coverage reports tests are executed?
Changes LGTM. Could you update the description?
LGTM, indeed please update commit message per guidelines (jira issue in subject).

@bolkedebruin, try to search them here: https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-airflow/jobs/232754162
I can't see them. But in run with this fix - I see them: https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-airflow/jobs/232805023
@bolkedebruin good catch. I've fixed this now.

@bolkedebruin could we get this merged? Thanks :)

Good point @hgrif, the previous implementation was done using the `.communicate()`, so I didn't want to change it too much. Also I see that the BashOperator has the [same piece of code](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/operators/bash_operator.py#L90) using `.wait()`.

I've [created a ticket to consolidate the way of logging](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-1224?jql=project%20%3D%20AIRFLOW), because we are implementing this piece over code in quite a few hooks.

Anyway, I've changed it using `.wait()` and rebased against master.

Please retrigger @Fokko to see if error is persistent.
We badly need this fix, as Airflow doesn't work with Python 3.4 on Ubuntu Linux. It looks like it hasn't worked since 3.x started including the timezone in datetime.now().

I've rebuild it on my repo, and the error is gone:
https://travis-ci.org/Fokko/incubator-airflow/builds/233522547

Also the failed test is not relevant for the part I've changed:
```
======================================================================
14) FAIL: test_trigger_dag_for_date (tests.www.api.experimental.test_endpoints.ApiExperimentalTests)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
   Traceback (most recent call last):
    tests/www/api/experimental/test_endpoints.py line 87 in test_trigger_dag_for_date
      self.assertEqual(200, response.status_code)
   AssertionError: 200 != 404
```

Note that making Airflow use timezones in dates is hard. You have to fix all the datetime.now()s, the datetime.today()s, the static datetime()s and the Column(Datetime)s. And after doing all that, some things still don't want to work.

The other way is this: find airflow -type f -print0 | xargs -0 sed -i 's/datetime\.now()/datetime\.now(tz=None)/g'

This should work, and takes a couple of minutes. Will see how it does in tests.
Small nit: the Exception thrown when the return code is not falsy is less informative than before. Maybe good to mention that it's a Sqoop command and log `cmd`?
LGTM
@Fokko ^^

Sorry, as I have to merge the commit (2 commits) please update your commit messages (**both**) per guidelines.

    1. Subject is separated from body by a blank line
    2. Subject is limited to 50 characters
    3. Subject does not end with a period
    4. Subject uses the imperative mood ("add", not "adding")
    5. Body wraps at 72 characters
    6. Body explains "what" and "why", not "how"

@rjurney many are using airflow on py34, tests also fully pass, so at the moment Im treating your issue as anecdotal.

Column(DateTimes) do no need to be fixed if we store everything in UTC and retrieve every date time in UTC. Timezone handling is different from that.

One of the reasons I did not put this in, is because of the password in the command. I now log the command, but mask the password. Also extended the tests a bit and fixed a small bug: When the `--num-mappers` is not set, it will end up as a `None` because we cast it to a string right away, now this is fixed by first checking if it actually set.

Cheers
Makes sense, cool!

Please note that even [google-cloud-dataflow-0.6.0](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/google-cloud-dataflow/0.6.0) which is up-to-date in pypi already removed DataflowPipelineRunner from its supported names. 
The new name got introduced in 0.5.1 and the old name is officially removed in 0.6.0 ([release note](https://cloud.google.com/dataflow/release-notes/release-notes-python)).

I know this is a breaking change, but anybody starting airflow today by `pip install apache-airflow google-cloud-dataflow` will get the error "DataflowPipelineRunner is not a valid PipelineRunner name."
Allright, I'm wondering if we should note this in UPDATING.md. So people are warned, as this is master this would be a new Airflow 1.9 section.
Added a note. Is it the correct place?
